comments.commentBody: So I guess its not that magical as too cool itself when it gets hot?? Maybe I will wait for version 2.

Really the heat is less of an event than the WiFi networking difficulties that many iPad owners have experienced.

Owners are being told to go reformat routers, and alter their iPad screen brightness control to improve WiFi reception. What?

Hey, I can't make this stuff up.

the kindle makes perfect sense if you're are a book reader and nothing else.  The high cost is well justified with lower cost of ownership from printed books.  as for magazine types of subscriptions, the kindle really needs color to make the stories compelling.  perhaps the next kindle DX will have that new color eInk technology.  at that pt, i would consider a kindle for its long last battery life and content that i want to enjoy in color.

The point that is made that really resonates is that someone should have told this girl to think better of her decision. However, going in to college I (and I'm sure she) had to sign documents that told me what I was going to owe coming out. Knowing I was going to have a comparably reasonable $45,000 in debt made me sign up for an economics class and buy a personal finance book, and quite honestly has been a soul wrenching lesson over the years since I graduated, as I watch my more privileged friends take jobs in writing, art, theater, and music, and ask their parents to pay the rent. I work in wealth management now primarily because I want to be able to understand this stuff better and teach it to others, but I suffer over what I've been told was the 'low price of my soul.'

How about making some more reasonable points, such as the fact that Citi and others charge double digit interest for loans that the state has basically made un-extinguishable (returns are supposed to be lower on lower risk securities)? How about colleges are buying fancy new buildings and renovating their dorms and gyms to keep up with each other in a race to tempt the 'rich kids,' while hiking up costs for all of their students? In preparing financial plans, my company models the future expense of college at 2% more than inflation (this is the only expense modeled that way) as a result. How about athletic scholarships that come with 'food allowances' that allow many athletes to subsidize their (free) education with unlimited meals while their peers live on macaroni and cheese at the end of the semester? How about there being no required practical link between a 'liberal arts education' and a monthly rent check, not even in the way of subtle advice or professional life skills? How about choosing to do what is necessary instead of what you love as a career? How about middle class kids being unable (or unwilling) to continue on to graduate school because they don't like the idea of adding another $100,000 (plus lost wages) to what that they already owe, and therefore killing the chance of a higher salary in the future. Or even worse, these kids could realize that they must go to graduate school because their undergrad education doesn't qualify them to operate a cash register.

The author said "perhaps the bank worried that once it approved one loan, cutting her off would have led her to drop out or transfer and have trouble paying back the loan."
How about perhaps she was old enough to go to war, smoke cigarettes, and probably spend plenty of that $100,000 on food, drinks, and fun in lower Manhattan with her classmates, not to mention legally sign that she knew what she was doing? Doctors can only tell you not to eat fatty foods - it's not their fault if you have a heart attack!

Also, please don't include a picture of Cortney looking forlorn in front of Citi with her shiny bike. I ride 40+ miles a week and had to choose to get a rusty secondhand bike from the 1980s because I'm paying my loans. Someone else makes the point that $850 per month is plenty to live on - I second that with enthusiasm. You don't have to look hard to find someone who will elicit more sympathy to make your point, but adding up her numbers does not make me feel sorry for her situation.
Gold bullion.

Mr. Steven Hayworth in the related column is making a terrible mistake.  He thinks that the important thing is for his daughter to work to learn the value of the dollar, and he's delighted that she's working in a clothing store.  But I have grown up beside the wealthiest elite of NY and NJ, I can say that just appreciating the dollar is not what has differentiated my hard-working friends from the ones that have never found a way to commit themselves.  What mattered was that some of my friends learned that work can be rewarding and THIS is what makes them driven.  Mr. Hayworth's daughter will only learn that working in a clothing store in monotonous, and what a lost opportunity for a crucial lesson this will be!

Unequivocally, it is Cortney Munna's responsibility.  She agreed to take out a loan, she is responsbile.  No questions, no other assignment of blame.  Take responsibility to your own actions.  I worked through college and paid for it along the way, it took me longer to get through, but I graduated without debt.

When you are 18 years old and a student at a premiere college you are old enough to make the correct decisions.

I don't even understand the problem here: she has take home of $2200, and rent of $750 and loan bills of $700/month. WHAT is the problem? If you can't live on $750/month in money for food clothes and fun you need some discipline. I paid off student debt of $60,000 at $400-$800 a month with a rent of $700 on a starting salary of $35k. AND I put money into savings. Again, what is the problem other than whininess here?

MAKE YOUR OWN MEALS, BUY REASONABLE COST CLOTHES AND SHUT UP PLEASE.

Neither a borrower nor a lender be;
For loan oft loses both itself and friend,(80)
And borrowing dulls the edge of husbandry.
This above all: to thine own self be true,
And it must follow, as the night the day,
Thou canst not then be false to any man.
Farewell. My blessing season this in thee!

Student loans are a regressive tax to fund education for those whose parents can't or won't pay for college for them. When students graduate they are saddled with debt that forces them to defer building assets and starting families, and in turn impairs their ability to help with their own children's education, thus perpetuating the cycle of debt.
Move to Vegas and get a job as a cocktail waitress/valet person/dancer.  no degree needed.  You'll make 6-digits and pay off your debt in no time.

How about the fact that you could have gotten your education from a state school at less than half the cost? How about you're working in a job that requires little or no education and certainly not in the field you majored in?

What do you plan to do with this overpriced education?

It boggles my mind that she would pick RELIGION and WS for her two majors with that kind of debt. Let shave a bit of common sense here. What did kind of job did she expect to get with that kind of background? NYU is good, but it isn't exactly an Ivy. I applaud her interest in those subjects and the courage it took to choose those majors instead of a greedy little business degree. But NYU's job was to get her through school, not coddle a very intelligent, independent woman about her life choices. Citigroup is a bank, whose sole interest is making money, so they can hardly be blamed either. Ms. Munna carries the blame for avoiding a   practical major. For any college-bound readers out there, try tacking on a Computer Science degree or at least a minor in Biotechnology if you are going to need that kind of dough after you graduate.

It is unfortunate that Ms. Munna and her mother did not spend time thinking of the future beyond getting a foot into "the best school". It is the same short sightedness adopted by individuals who got into mortgages they could not afford. These situations are not the fault of the lenders. Yes, very bad lending practices were followed, but it is always the responsibility of the borrower to ensure that the loan fits in with their current and future financial goals. Investments are the same. When an investor takes a risk and it comes out bad, unless the person was scammed, it is generally accepted that the investor assumed the risk on his own and lost. The same should be said for borrowing. The borrowers gamble on the chance that their adjustable rate mortgages would not sky rocket. The students gamble on the chance that a college degree will ensure sufficient income to pay the loan. In all cases, if the borrower/investor takes a litle time to consider past experiences (both their own and others) and present financial state as well as map out their financial future, even in very simple layman terms, he/she can avoid these financial pitfalls. Last but not least, there exists a parental responsibility to teach children the basics of money management. By the time their children are of college age, most parents will have had many financial experiences, both ups and downs, from which to draw upon and teach their children the basics of money management. There is simply no excuse for parents "aiding and abetting" their children's poor financial choices.

It seems pretty obvious that children follow their parents' example. Often that example is transferred by behavior, not words. Hypocrisy in word over deed may even make the lesson more sticky.

Despite all the anecdotal examples here, people's attitudes towards money are not correlated to class. Money is a weird, highly-charged material for all of us. Figuring out our own attitude towards it is a good idea before having kids.

I think the last part of Munna's post says it all--"It was always just the next step to take: Get into good school. Get decent scholarship."
I was lucky enough to graduate without burdensome debt only because my father looked out for me. I had no idea whether my debt load was manageable. High school is like a high-speed train with a connection to another high-speed train (college). Perhaps making school less of a track, and engaging students in true life choices (by studying abroad for a year, say, or working their way through college) might help them make decisions about finance and education as adults, rather than children, as Ms. Munna and I did.

It is always someone's else fault? once they start getting their own apartments and buying their own furniture, etc, they started to be accountable. The university can place some safeguards. But the ultimate responsibility falls to the individual..Parents can help out...advise and all that.
She chose an expensive university and choose to go to the most expensive city for apartments. and whose stupid idea was it to take night classes to defer payments. The best thing for her to do is to move back with her parents because living accommodation is the most expensive part of survival. Next is taxes(if her parents are in a low tax area, great)
Tuiton fees have gone sky high but she should have gone to a community college. hindsight is 20/20.
I have no pity on this pretty young lady and I think that it is a non story as there are so many other people who are dealing with debt not as a result of such stupidity but because of life such as family illnesses, etc etc.
I would suggest to Ron to interview people with a more deserving story.

Mr. Lieber is missing a few facts about student loans and the student loan industry. Although he cites CitiBank as an equivalent to the sub-prime lenders, he neglects to describe the extraordinary lengths that the student loan industry has gone to keep their industry from being regulated, transparent, and fair to consumers.  Even before Sallie Mae was privatized from the quasi-government organization it started out as, it has been ruthlessly marketing itself to colleges with questionable pricing discounts for loan-related services, lobbying government to exempt student loans from bankruptcy laws, and almost succeeded in keeping an arcane rule from being repealed.  The "single lender rule" prohibited the borrower from refinancing a student loan with any other lender.  I had my student loans deferred while I was in the military so the interest continued to accrue.  Then I borrowed more to complete school after I'd left the military. I was able to force Sallie Mae to transfer my loan to the government but I'm 47 now, and I will be paying this loan until I retire.

When I read just the title of this article I wanted to start laughing.  I am in the same situation with over 70k in student loan debt...from attending private universities including NYU and have not graduated yet because I left school because of all the bills in my third year.  I believe school financial aid offices need to council students at the beginning of every semester you take at more loans.  After my deferment was up I did not have enough money to pay some of my loans went into default.  I had no idea that I could have tried to get a deferment until years later when I want to straighten out my credit.  I also did not know that if your loans are in default you can consolidate your student loans and they have an income sensitive repayment plan that is based on the income you make...so it is flexible.  I also read about the plan that Obama just passed which will drop off some of your student loans if you work in public service and that if you are over I think 50k or 70k in student loans you only have to pay for 30 years and that's it regardless if you have not paid off the entire loan.  None of these things did I know when I was in school....not one loan counselor informed me of the options available to me.  Also if I could do it again I probably would have went to a state school and spent 50k less money and still received a decent education....but as they say you live and you learn....sometimes life experience is a better teacher than any school!

When our daughter was young, we felt it was important to teach her how to do 3 things:  To earn money, to save money, and to spend money wisely.  Therefore, she had to earn twice the amount of whatever she wanted to buy, so she could save half and spend half.  As a result, she is now leaving law school with a very low level of debt - far lower than many of her compatriots - in part because of her life-long saving habit.

Please.  I watched 65 dissolve, and since 65 is the new 35, I figured I'd gained something there....my 79-year old husband is 12 years into his 3rd career, with no end in sight (and, irony of ironies, not only does he pay taxes on 85% of his Social Security, he also STILL pays into the fund in the form of taxes.  At 79.).  Thanks to the current markets,  I will not retire in my lifetime.  He's tired, I would like to babysit my grandchildren.  None of that seems to matter to anyone.  I know I need to take care of the future generations - but I'd like to be able do it in person, not via e-mail because I need to pay those taxes.  So, please.  Don't make these ages any higher, or there will really be no one to care for the future.

Yes, we all need to work longer so we can make Wall Street CEOs even richer.  The military-industrial complex needs more work-hours, people, so every one needs to give 110%.  Why do we even work that long? We should be discussing 4 hours-workdays or 3 days-workweeks.  But if we did that, the people at the top of the pyramid would have to settle for smaller mansions; we can't have that.  And having a lot of people with free time on their hands isn't good for our corporate-run form of government either.  You give people time to think and organize, the next thing you know they might demand a better breed of politicians...

Hmm. How come one can be a supreme court justice or a senator well up into one's eighties? Are these jobs so undemanding of strength and mental acuity? Perhaps that explains some things...
It's disgraceful that the economics of SS and medicare have been allowed to deteriorate to this point. No-one wants to pay the piper. We all want higher benefits and lower taxes. Time to get real. But we almost-retirees had been promised SS for decades, and perhaps counted on it. We could have had a better retirement fund if we'd invested that money ourselves--if we'd been allowed. If the government messed up the investing or the funds (a ponzie scheme, for anyone else) then one should hold THEM responsible. Trouble is, who is "them?" As Pogo once said, we have met the enemy and it is us.....

Most of the 230 comments and 7 article contributors need to clear their minds a bit and get a grip on reality. Plentiful long term living wage jobs for tthe MAJORITY of americans to attain the "dream" is no longer the norm and you all should have a clue as to why by now. Raising the retirement age is not only ridiculous but will only exacerbate the already dreadful unemployment problem for millions of younger workers desperately seeking meaningful work. May I propose a few humble solutions:
1. Lower the full retirement age to at least 60. This will open up a multitude of jobs to so many unemployed who WANT to work.
2. Scrap the Cap on the limit of earnings one makes to cease making contributions into the Social Security(Medicare) system.
3. The U.S. government must make a concerted effort to bring back good paying manufacturing jobs and make it economically prohibitive for greed driven corporations to relocate to foreign countries with no thought or responsibility to the future of this country, its people, or the rest of the world.
4. A gradual and deliberate conversion of a war based economy and a planetary degradation system to one that works in conjunction with the environment and the well being of all life on this fragile planet by rebuilding our crumbling infrastructure and leading the way in pioneering clean and sustainable energy alternatives for openers.
5. Bring back the estate and capital gains taxes that only benefit the few and not the many, to where they should be, for starters. Eliminate all the tax loop holes that allow the rich to keep getting richer and have every american pay his or her fair share most likely through a flat-tax on ALL income including exec's "deferred compensation packages."
5. Resurrect the "Good Neighbor" policy proposed by FDR and help raise the living standards of the millions of impoverished people living south of our border and elsewhere around the globe without the current criminal practices of inhuman exploitation that is the S.O.P. of many a U.S. and European corporation.
These are just a few suggestions for some long term solutions for the serious problems of our own making. Sooner or later the people will have to act for the survival of this planet and themselves. In solidarity and justice for all.

The anti-union, anti-pension movement is trying to force older - more expensive - employees, 50 and over, out of the workforce. "Bring in those new and enthusiastic new teachers, out with the old deadwood!", etc.

The second prong of this attack is to not allow these unemployed -- "retirees" -- to be able to collect retirement until they reach mid to late 60's.

Very clever.
